explanation:
For a correct dead‑code (MISRA) analysis we must know which operations in ahc_echo can affect observable program behaviour and which branches can actually matter; the following symbols are required and why:

- strcmp: used to test HTTP method; required to determine reachability of the whole handler (early MHD_NO return).
- MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET: the constant compared against method; needed to evaluate the method check’s effect on reachability.
- MHD_NO / MHD_YES: return/result values from the handler; required to know whether removing code would change return behaviour.
- aptr (static request marker): the address used as a rendezvous marker across calls; required to decide whether the "first call do-nothing" branch is reachable/meaningful.
- req_cls (request-specific state pointer): pointer used with &aptr; needed to determine the two-call handshake branch (stateful behaviour) and whether the first-call early return is live code.
- fopen: opens the requested file; required to decide whether the file-serving branch can be entered (file vs directory vs error paths).
- fileno: used after fopen; required to determine whether the subsequent fstat branch is exercised or an internal error path occurs.
- fclose: closes file; required because removing closes or the file-handling branch could change resource/behaviour.
- fstat: used to detect file type/size; required to decide whether the code classifies the opened target as a regular file (serving branch) or falls back to directory/error handling.
- S_ISREG: macro used to check st_mode; required to decide whether the file-serving branch is reached.
- opendir: used when fopen fails or target not regular; required to evaluate directory-serving branch reachability and side effects.
- closedir: used to clean up dir on failure; required for resource‑effect analysis.
- errno: used when snprintfing the error message; required because the error message and the chosen response depend on errno.
- strerror: used to produce the error message; required to know whether removal of the error-path message changes observable output.
- snprintf: used to build the error message; required to evaluate whether that formatting operation is observable (affects response body length/content).
- strlen: used to determine length of emsg for response creation; required to know whether response body length (and thus the response) would change if message construction were removed.
- struct stat (st_mode, st_size): st_mode used to test S_ISREG, st_size used to set response size; required because these influence which response creation branch is taken and the declared body length.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer: used to create the error response from emsg; required because creation-vs-noncreation affects whether a response is queued and so is observable behaviour.
- MHD_RESPMEM_MUST_COPY: memory policy passed to create_response_from_buffer; required to understand ownership and whether removing the buffer or copying changes behaviour.
- MHD_create_response_from_callback: used to build both directory and file streaming responses; required because it determines which streaming path is used and whether callbacks (dir_reader/file_reader) are invoked.
- MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN: used when creating directory response; required to determine how response size semantics affect behaviour.
- MHD_queue_response: queues the created response on the connection (core observable action); required because most branches end by calling it — removing or altering calls here would change externally visible behaviour.
- MHD_destroy_response: cleans up the response object after queuing; required to know whether resource cleanup is necessary/observable and whether removal changes lifetime/behaviour.
- dir_reader: callback used to stream directory contents; required because its invocation is an externally observable side effect (data sent), so its reachability matters for dead code analysis.
- dir_free_callback: free callback for dir; required to know resource lifetime and whether removing associated code would change behaviour.
- file_reader: callback used to stream file contents; required because its invocation sends file data (observable) and determines whether the file-serving branch is live.
- file_free_callback: free callback for file; required for correct lifetime/side‑effect analysis of file-streaming branch.
- MHD_HTTP_SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE / MHD_HTTP_OK: response status codes used for queued responses; required because they are externally observable results (status changes). 

In short: the above symbols cover control-flow decisions (method test, req_cls/aptr handshake), I/O and file-vs-directory branching (fopen/fileno/fstat/S_ISREG/opendir), error-message construction (errno/strerror/snprintf/strlen), response creation/queuing/destruction (MHD_create_response_from_* , MHD_queue_response, MHD_destroy_response, response memory policies, status codes), and the streaming callbacks that produce observable output (dir_reader/file_reader and their free callbacks). Knowing the semantics and side effects of these symbols is necessary to determine whether any statements in ahc_echo are truly dead (their removal would not affect externally observable behaviour or resource/timing effects).
